subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: keyboard map uploaded

messageBody:
ouphrontis wrote:
Hi,

I would like to add to my keyboard idea that it is better to make a
complete break with the Orthodox ways and just go for the most
efficient layout. If the layout follows the 'qwerty' way we inherit
some cruft that people might have to live with a looong time. Let's
reuse Dvorak's keyboard ideas.
Learning to touch type on a totally new keyboard layout might be helped by having a help screen which could appear at the bottom of the screen when a "hot key" is activated, which would toggle the layout on and off.  It shouldn't take too much time, to learn the positions of the QS letters in this layout.  Not being a programmer, I don't know how much trouble this would be.
This alphabet is meant to replace the old way completely so a
keyboard mapping should not get rid of useful symbols. Some missing
symbols in Oliver's mapping are necessary for programming and other
tasks. Let's not get rid of them.
This seems sensible.
Also, as to the unicode proposal, why not just *re-use* the Shavian
mapping which is already there? There is no 'obligation' to display
exactly the glyphs as in the standard (per the standard). What needs
to be added is a couple of symbols to reach Junior QS. That is all.
But I think that the proposal should not only aim for that but to
attempt to include Senior QS. An effort needs to be made to find all
possible ligatures, half letters, zig-zag cases and develop ways fit
I agree.  Part of the fun of QS are the interesting word shapes made with the half-letters.  I have no data to back this up, but I would expect that the varied word shapes should aid new readers in decyphering text more quickly than in more similarly-appearing shapes.

Another possible order that might be nice is one win which the order
is determined by the frequency of the character appearing after the
preceeding character in the order. For example, the first letter would
be the one with which the majority of words start. The second, the one
that most commonly follows the first in words etc. Is this a good
idea?

This doesn't seem as useful to me as just a simple frequency order, i.e. so that the most frequently used letter appears first, the next most frequently used letter appears second, etc.  This means the seldom used letters appear at the end, and it lets the student see in an unforgettable way which letters he should learn first and which last (as far as need goes).  Of course, the order in which the alphabet is listed, as in a dictionary, does not indicate the order in which the letters should appear in a teaching text.  It still seems that it makes sense to group letters according to categories - consonants vs. vowels, voiced vs. unvoiced, etc.
Finally, an even crazier idea. How about a locale en_jQS? Take a linux
(or some other malleable OS) installation, translate all the message
catalogs into Junior QS (with simple software and a dictionay this can
be done rather easily I think -- except for the lack of a monospace
font for JQS). Voila! The entire system in QS (almost)!
I don't even know what JQS is!
This is only my second post (as far as I know) to this group so sorry
if these ideas are old and have been rehashed as nauseum in the past.
Please tell me if that is the case.
I think you have some very interesting ideas, and you clearly should be posting more frequently.

Paige G.
